main_text:
Classical Period || Texts of the early classical period
3.1 Texts of the early classical period

The texts relevant to the study of the development of logic during
this period may be divided into three kinds: those which have
arguments but which do not mention or discuss either argument or
inference as such, those which mention or discuss inference as such
but do not mention or discuss arguments as such, and those which
mention or discuss arguments and possibly also mention or discuss
inference, and may even provide illustrations of either.
3.1.1 Texts with arguments

During this period polemical texts, which consist almost entirely of
arguments, start to appear. The earliest among these are texts
attributed to Nāgārjuna (2nd century ce),
among which are the
Mūla-madhyama-kakārikā (Basic verses on
the middle way), the Vigrahavyāvartanı̄
(Exclusion of disputes) and the
Vaidalya-prakaraṇa (Tract on pulverization).
Shortly thereafter came a text by Āryadeva (c. 3rd century ce),
said to be a student of Nāgārjuna,
entitled Śataka-śāstra (Treatise in one
hundred verses), now extant only in its Chinese translation,
Bǎi lùn (百論). Of these texts, only
the Vaidalya-prakaraṇa is a prose text. While the
others are in verse, the Vigraha-vyāvartanı̄
and the Śataka-śāstra, unlike the
Mūla-madhyama-kakārikā, are accompanied by the
author’s own commentary. Of the latter two, only the
Vigraha-yāvartanı̄ survives in its Sanskrit
original. That the text has a commentary by its author and that both
the text and the commentary have survived in the original Sanskrit
original make it the text which best reveals the reasoning of the
period.

The text comprises seventy verses, each supplemented with the
author’s own commentary. The central question addressed is the
claim that nothing has a nature. The first twenty verses present four
arguments supporting the claim followed by six arguments against it.
The following fifty verses elaborate on the arguments and objections
in the first twenty. The argumentation in the text is complex, using a
number of different forms of argument and invoking or presupposing
several principles of reasoning. To appreciate the kind of reasoning
found in this and the other texts mentioned above, we shall consider
briefly some of the arguments found in verses 31–50 and in their
accompanying commentary.

Nāgārjuna’s aim in the verses 31–50 is to show
that any argument to establish that there are
pramāṇas, means of epistemic cognition, ultimately
leads to contradiction. He considers two cases: the case where it is
maintained that pramāṇas are established by other
pramāṇas and the case where each
pramāṇa establishes itself. The first case is
addressed in verse 31 and its accompanying commentary, where
Nāgārjuna argues that, if to establish a
pramāṇa other pramāṇas are
required, then there results an endless (an-avasthā :
literally, foundationless) chain of such pramāṇas, in other
words, an infinite regress, which is taken to be an impossibility. The
second case spans the remaining verses (33–50) and has two
parts. In the first part (vv. 33–39), the proponent of the
existence of pramāṇas is challenged to justify
why, of all the things whose existence is established by
pramāṇas, pramāṇas alone have
the peculiarity of not being established by (other)
pramāṇas. The opponent’s answer is to
maintain that pramāṇas are not alone; light too,
the opponent claims, has the property of revealing the existence both
of other things and itself. Nāgārjuna then puts forth four
arguments to show either that light does not reveal itself or that it
does not reveal anything. In the second part (vv. 40–48),
Nāgārjuna maintains that a pramāṇa and
its prameya, the object revealed by the
pramāṇa, are indistinguishable, which he seems to
think is absurd. He goes on to bolster this argument with what he
takes to be, and what he says is, another argument of the very same
form, and which concludes father and his son, by dint of their
relation, are indistinguishable (vv. 49–50).

With the argumentative structure of the passage in mind, let us
consider three arguments in it which can be understood without
elaboration. In verse 34, Nāgārjuna says:


For fire does not illuminate itself. Just as a pot in the dark, not
yet illuminated by fire, is not apprehended, and then at the very next
moment, illuminated by fire, is apprehended as existent, in the very
same way, if a fire were in the dark, not yet illuminated [and] at a
later time there were be [its] illumination by fire, then it would
illuminate its existence. Yet that is not so.


The point is that, while the opponent holds that a
pramāṇa is self revealing, fire is not. When fire
illuminates something, the thing the fire illuminates already exists
in the dark before the fire’s light reveals it; but a fire does
not exist in the dark before the fire’s light reveals it. In
this way, Nāgārjuna has shown that the opponent has failed
to show that there is anything other than pramāṇas
which are self revealing and that therefore the
pramāṇas remain exceptional.

This argument has, even to modern eyes, prima facie merit.
However, the next two arguments do not. The argument in verse 35 is
restated in the

commentary as follows:


And if, according to what you say, a fire illuminates its own
existence in the very same way as it illuminates the existence of
other things too, will it not burn itself in the very same way as it
burns other things too?


The argument is this: Fire illuminates other things and itself. Fire
burns other things. Therefore fire burns itself. But fire does not
burn itself. Therefore fire does not illuminate itself. The argument
is framed as an argument by reductio ad impossibile with an
argument by analogy within. As it happens, this argument by analogy is
easily recast in the form of an analogical argument through
similarity, one of two forms of argument treated as canonical in other
texts and to be discussed below. We can see that the argument here has
no deductive cogency, if we render the argument as deductive by
supplying the following premiss: if fire bears one relationship to
other things and to itself, then any other relationship it bears to
other things it bears to itself.

An equally unconvincing argument is given in the next verse (36).


And if, according to your thinking, fire illuminates its existence and
that of other things, would not darkness, being the opposite of fire,
also hide its existence and that of other things? Yet that is not
observed. In that case, your statement that fire illuminates its own
existence and that of other things is not true.


The argument here is also framed as an argument by reductio ad
impossibile with an argument by analogy within. As it happens,
this argument by analogy is easily recast in the form of an analogical
argument through dissimilarity, the other of two forms of argument
treated as canonical in other texts and to be discussed below.
3.1.2 Texts discussing inference

We know of four texts from this period which identify inference
(anumāna), as distinguished from argument
(sādhana), as a means of epistemic cognition
(pramāṇa). They are the
Vaiśeṣika-sūtra (Aphorisms on
individuation), a treatise of speculative ontology attributed to
Kaṇāda (c. 1st century ce), the
Spitzer manuscript, a collection of fragments of a Sanskrit text (c.
3rd century ce) of unknown authorship (Franco,
2004, v. 1, 32–33), Saṃdhi-nirmocana-sūtra
(Aphorisms on release from bondage), an early Mahāyana
text (between the 3rd and 5th centuries ce),
also of unknown authorship, and the
Ṣaṣṭi-tantra (Sixty doctrines), a
Sāṃkhya text attributed Vārṣagaṇya (4th
century ce).

The Vaiśeṣika-sūtra has passages which allude
to inferences whereby one unobserved thing is inferred on the basis of
something observed which bears one of five relations to the thing
inferred (VS 9.18; Jambuvijaya (ed), 1961, 69; cp. VS 3.1.8). However,
no examples are given. In contrast, six examples of inference are
found in the Spitzer manuscript among the surviving fragments
referring to the four means of epistemic cognition
(pramāṇas) of perception
(pratyakṣa), inference (anumāna), analogy
(aupamya) and tradition (aitihya) (Franco, 2003,
126), though these inferences require piecing together (Franco, 2003,
126–136). A passage which also refers to the same
pramāṇas but with different words

is found in the tenth and last chapter of the
Saṃdhi-nirmocana-sūtra, an early Mahāyana
Buddhist text, of unknown authorship, which survives only in a Tibetan
and Chinese translation. The passage in question has also been
translated into English and critically discussed by Yoshimizu (2010,
142–148). (See also Powers (trans.), 1991, 321ff.)

Finally, there is the Ṣaṣṭi-tantra, which
also survives only in fragments, first collected by Frauwallner
(1958), later expanded by Steinkellner (2017, Appendix 1). It defines
inference (anumāna) as follows: To infer is to establish
something in the remainder, on the basis of a relation and something
perceptible. One of the text’s fragments lists six relations as
ones which underpin an acceptable inference. They are: the master
servant relation (sva-svāmi-bhāva-saṃbandha),
the matter alteration relation
(prakṛti-vikāra-saṃbandha), the part whole
relation (kārya-kāraṇa-saṃbandha), the
cause effect relation (nimitta-naimittika-saṃbandha),
the source product relation
(mātrā-mātrika-saṃbandha), the
association relation (sahacāri-saṃbandha) and the
incompatibility relation
(vadhya-ghātaka-saṃbandha). Though each of the
relations is illustrated, no example of an inference using them is
found among the known fragments.

What emerges from the passages of the
Vaiśeṣika-sūtra and the
Ṣaṣṭi-tantra and what is consistent with
those in the Spitzer manuscript and
Saṃdhi-nirmocana-sūtra is that inferences have the
following form:

inferential syllogism



proposition:
p has S 

reason:
because p has H. 

relation:
A relation which possessors of H bear to possessors of S.
 


3.1.3 Texts discussing argument

Interest in the nature of argument itself appears also at this time.
The best known text from this period is the Brahmanical treatise
Nyāya-sūtra (Aphorisms on logic) by
Gautama, also known as Akṣapāda (c. 2nd ce),
the actual redaction of which is thought by
some to date to the third century ce. This
concerns topics primarily pertaining to epistemology and debate.
Though a few aphorisms found in the first chapter of the first and
second books speak of inference, much more attention is devoted to
debate, essentially all of both chapters of Book 5, the entirety of
the second chapter of Book 1, and several aphorisms in the first
chapter of Book 1. Unfortunately, the text’s aphorisms
(sūtras) are often not much more than lists of terms.
With little discussion and few examples, it is hard to get a clear
idea of what the key terms mean.

Some light is shed on this work by a contemporaneous Buddhist work,
Nāgārjuna's Vaidalya-prakaraṇa, mentioned
above. It is organized around the key terms listed in the first
aphorism of the Nyāya-sūtra (NS 1.1.1). However, it
does not explain the terms nor does it illustrate them. Instead, it
sets out for each term arguments intended to show its incoherence. It
is therefore rich in arguments, most of which are analogical. The
author also judges a number of counter arguments as fallacious,
pointing out either that they are circular or that they lead to an
infinite regress.

Less laconic passages pertaining to some of the same topics are found
in the Caraka-saṃhitā, Classical India’s
earliest medical text, conjectured by some to have been redacted in
its current form at the beginning of first century ce.
The text has three relevant passages: a short
one concerned with inference (CS 1.11.21–22), a longer one
concerned with pramāṇas (CS 3.4.1–14 ) and a
still longer one concerned with argument (CS 3.8.16–67).

Not all Buddhist texts from this period are hostile to argumentation.
Two works contain short passages with lists and classificatory
definitions of terms pertaining to debate. One is the
Saṃdhi-nirmocana-sūtra (Aphorisms on release
from bondage), mentioned above. Another is the
Abhidharma-samuccaya (Compendium of the higher
teachings), a text usually attributed to the Buddhist thinker,
Asaṅga (5th century ce), whose fifth
chapter has a section, its seventh, often referred to as
Vāda-viniścaya (Settling on what debate
is), also devoted to debate.

In contrast to the passages in the two texts just mentioned, which
list, and even sometimes gloss, terms ive other texts from this period
not only mention and sometimes discuss, terms pertinent to inference
and debate the Yogācāra-bhūmi-śāstra
(Treatise on the stages of the practice of yoga), a work
traditionally attributed to Asaṅga, but now generally thought to
be by a number of authors, has a passage, usually referred to as
Hetu-vidyā (Science of reasons), which provides
some fifty examples of simple common sense inferences, all of which
are easily recast in the form of the inferential syllogism given
above. The inferences are divided into five categories. While relation
words are used for each category, the logical force of these relations
is not made clear. The inferences provided include ones such as the
inference of fire from smoke, of the presence of a lion from its roar,
of being sick from unusual eating practices, as well as inferences
more closely connected with Buddhist doctrine.

There are two other works which have passages pertinent to the study
of the history of reasoning in India, both works attributed to
Asaṅga. The first is the Xiǎn yáng shèng
jiào lùn
(顯揚聖教論), or Treatise which
reveals and disseminates the wise teachings, which is a condensed
version of the
Yogācāra-bhūmi-śāstra, and the
Shùn zhōng lùn (順中論),
or Treatise on following the middle way, which seems to be a
commentary on the introductory verse of Nāgārjuna’s
Mūla-madhyamaka-kārikā (Katsura 1985 p.
166).

The first work devoted entirely to argument and inference is the
Fāng biàn xīn lùn
(方便心論), or Treatise on the heart of
means, translated into Chinese in 472 ce
without attribution, though it later came to be attributed to
Nāgārjuna. This text, translated into Sanskrit by G. Tucci
(1929), is commonly known by scholars by the translation of its title
by Tucci as Upāya-hṛdaya.

Finally, shortly after Asaṅga, Vasubandhu (c. 5th century ce),
another Buddhist idealist, thought to be the
younger brother of the Asaṅga, wrote at least three works on
debate: Vāda-hṛdaya (Heart of debate),
Vāda-vidhāna (Precepts of debate) and
Vāda-vidhi (Rules of debate). These texts have
been lost, though fragments of the latter two, some in Sanskrit, many
in Tibetan, have been collected (Frauwallner 1933, 1957; Ono 2020).
Another work, ascribed to Vasubandhu, which survives only in Chinese,
is the Rúshí lùn
(如實論), Treatise on truth. G. Tucci
(1929), translating it back into Sanskrit, gave it the Sanskrit title
Tarka-śāstra, by which it is now generally known.
However, as has been shown recently by Ono Motoi (Ono 2020 §1),
this rendition is not correct.

Having surveyed the texts from the late preclassical period pertinent
to the study of the development of logic, we now turn to the emergence
of a canonical Indian syllogism.
